title: 113_s953
content: The "Student Loan Affordability Act" amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 to extend the interest rate deadline to July 1, 2015. It also includes modifications to required distribution rules for pension plans. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 requires that if an employee dies before their interest is fully distributed, the entire interest must be distributed within 5 years, with exceptions for eligible designated beneficiaries. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 amendment states that if an employee's interest is payable to an eligible designated beneficiary, the distribution must occur over the beneficiary's life expectancy starting within a year of the employee's death. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 amendment requires distributions to an eligible designated beneficiary to start within a year of the employee's death, unless specified otherwise by the Secretary's regulations. If the beneficiary is the surviving spouse, the distribution start date may differ. The distribution start date for an eligible designated beneficiary must not be earlier than when the employee would have turned 70 1/2. If the surviving spouse dies before receiving distributions, the spouse is treated as the employee. If an eligible designated beneficiary dies before their interest is fully distributed, certain rules apply to the remaining beneficiaries. The definition of an eligible designated beneficiary under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is any individual designated as a beneficiary by the employee. This individual must receive their portion within 5 years after their death. An eligible designated beneficiary, in relation to an employee, includes the surviving spouse, a minor child, a disabled individual, or a chronically ill person. An individual meeting specific requirements, including being a surviving spouse, minor child, disabled individual, or chronically ill person, or an individual not more than 10 years younger than the employee, is subject to special rules. An individual meeting specific requirements, such as being a surviving spouse, minor child, disabled individual, or chronically ill person, will cease to be an eligible designated beneficiary upon reaching majority. The distribution of any remaining portion of an employee's interest must occur within 5 years after reaching majority. Additionally, if an employee becomes a 5-percent owner after age 70 1/2, special rules apply. The amendments made by this section apply to distributions for employees who die after December 31, 2013. For employees becoming a 5-percent owner after age 70 1/2, special rules apply. Employees who become a 5-percent owner before January 1, 2013, and have not retired by 2014, will be treated as 5-percent owners for the year 2013 for tax purposes. The amendments made by subsection (c) apply to designated beneficiaries of employees who die before January 1, 2014. Existing annuity contracts in effect before the enactment of this Act are exempt from these amendments. The Act defines a "qualified annuity" as a commercial annuity or one payable by a defined benefit plan, with payments made regularly over the lives of the employee and a designated beneficiary. The Act defines a "qualified annuity" as a commercial annuity or one payable by a defined benefit plan, with payments made regularly over the lives of the employee and a designated beneficiary, in accordance with specific regulations. The Act allows for annuity payments to be made to the employee or designated beneficiaries, with the employee having the option to make an irrevocable election regarding the method and amount of the payments before the enactment of the Act. LIMITATION ON EARNINGS STRIPPING BY EXPATRIATED ENTITIES. Special rules for expatriated entities under subsection (j) of section 163 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include modifications for corporations, such as applying paragraph (2)(A) without certain conditions and adjusting paragraph (1)(B) without the parenthetical clause. The special rules for expatriated entities under subsection (j) of section 163 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 involve modifications for corporations, including adjustments to taxable income calculations in succeeding years. The term "expatriated entity" for a corporation in a taxable year is defined by section 7874(a)(2), excluding surrogate foreign corporations treated as domestic. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act for corporations treated as domestic under section 7874(b). SEC. 5. MODIFICATIONS RELATED TO THE OIL SPILL LIABILITY TRUST FUND. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include the definition of crude oil, removal of restrictions on oil wells, extension of the Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund financing rate, and a clerical amendment. The effective date of these amendments is specified. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including definitions and financing rates, will apply to crude oil and petroleum products received or entered after 60 days from the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. RESERVING RESULTING SURPLUSES FOR DEFICIT REDUCTION. The budgetary effects of this Act will not be included in the PAYGO scorecards.
